summary: This document is an email chain from October 2020 between an Assistant United States Attorney (AUSA) for the Southern District of New York and a NY CART Coordinator/Senior Forensic Examiner. They discuss the status of forensic imaging and video file extraction from multiple Mac computers seized in the Epstein investigation, noting delays and technical issues like a wiped drive.

persons.name: Assistant United States Attorney
persons.context: The AUSA from the Southern District of New York is coordinating with forensic examiners to obtain and review image and video files from seized Epstein devices, checking on ETAs and scheduling calls.

persons.name: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: The forensic examiner is responsible for processing seized Mac computers from the Epstein case, reporting on progress, technical issues (like a wiped drive), and delays due to equipment constraints and personal time off.

connections.person2: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
connections.description: Working together on the forensic examination of devices seized in the Epstein investigation, with the AUSA requesting files and updates, and the examiner providing technical status reports.

events.title: Forensic Examination Status Update
events.description: Email update on the slow progress of imaging and extracting video files from multiple Mac computers seized in the Epstein investigation, with expectations for more machines to be ready later in the week.
personsInvolved: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner

events.title: Coordination Call Scheduled
events.description: The AUSA and forensic examiner schedule a call to discuss the most efficient way to review the large volume of image and video files from the seized Epstein devices.
personsInvolved: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner

keyFacts: Forensic examiners were actively processing multiple Mac computers (e.g., NYC024328, NYC024329, NYC024353) seized in the Epstein investigation as of October 2020 to extract image and video files.
Device NYC024342 was identified as a wiped drive with no data recoverable, indicating potential evidence destruction.
The forensic process was described as going 'very slowly' due to equipment constraints, with examiners stacked up waiting for processing machines.

The email chain shows ongoing coordination between the U.S. Attorney's Office and forensic examiners well over a year after Epstein's death, indicating an active investigation into evidence from his devices.
